title-group.article-title: Biological mechanisms underlying adverse mental health outcome after trauma

trans-title-group.trans-title: Mecanismos biológicos subyacentes a las consecuencias adversas para la salud mental tras un trauma

title-group.alt-title: M. VAN ZUIDEN AND M. OLFF

The terms on which this article has been published allow the posting of the Accepted Manuscript in a repository by the author(s) or with their consent.

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: By now it is well known that trauma-related psychiatric disorders are associated with a broad range of biological dysregulations. This special issue focused on research aiming to advance our understanding of the biological mechanisms underlying adverse mental health outcome after trauma, in particular the development of trauma-related disorders and differences in individual susceptibility (i.e. risk or resilience) to their development. We included 51 papers published in EJPT between 2021 and 2023, either directly submitted to the special issue or whose focus clearly fitted the aim of the special issue. Included papers consisted of 43 original research papers and 8 review articles, addressing a wide range of biological processes, ranging from brain and central nervous system functioning, to cardiovascular and autonomic nervous system functioning; endocrinology; (epi)genetics; metabolism; inflammation; sleep and pain. Collectively, the included articles showcase that significant steps are taken in advancing our understanding of the biological mechanisms underlying development of and susceptibility to trauma-related disorders, as well their recovery. Recommendations for future research are provided with regard to study design; assessment of trauma exposure characteristics; sex and/or gender (minority)-related factors; geographic, developmental/lifespan and transgenerational aspects; and the temporal dynamics of biological processes in relation to the stage of the disorder under investigation. Together, these articles will hopefully further facilitate the development of more effective preventive, early and curative intervention strategies, as well as more effective timely and personalised allocation towards these interventions.

list-item.p: This special issue based on contains 51 papers showcases incremental knowledge about biological mechanisms of trauma-related disorder development, susceptibility and recovery.
More research is needed with more varied and understudied populations in terms of geographic location, developmental and aging perspectives.
Incorporation of trauma exposure characteristics and sex and/or gender effects into descriptive and analytic approaches is needed.
More precise information is needed on timing of biological measures in relation to the trauma exposure and the stage of the disorder.

trans-abstract.p: Hasta el momento es bien sabido que los trastornos psiquiátricos relacionados con trauma se asocian a una amplia gama de desregulaciones biológicas. Este número especial se centró en investigación destinada a profundizar nuestra comprensión de los mecanismos biológicos que subyacen a las consecuencias adversas para la salud mental tras un trauma, en particular el desarrollo de los trastornos relacionados con trauma y las diferencias en la susceptibilidad individual (es decir, riesgo o resiliencia) d su desarrollo. Se incluyeron 51 artículos publicados en la EJPT entre 2021-2023, ya sea enviados directamente al número especial o cuyo foco se ajustaba claramente al objetivo del mismo. Estos incluyeron 43 artículos de investigación originales y 8 artículos de revisión, que abordan una amplia gama de procesos biológicos, variando desde el funcionamiento cerebral y sistema nervioso central, al funcionamiento cardiovascular y sistema nervioso autónomo; endocrinología; (epi)genética; metabolismo; inflamación; sueño y dolor. Colectivamente, los artículos incorporados muestran que se están dando pasos importantes para avanzar en nuestra comprensión de los mecanismos biológicos subyacentes al desarrollo y la susceptibilidad a los trastornos relacionados con trauma, así como su recuperación. Se dieron recomendaciones para futuras investigaciones con respecto a diseño de estudio; evaluación de las características de exposición al trauma; factores relacionados con (minorías de) sexo y/o género; aspectos geográficos, del desarrollo/a lo largo de la vida y transgeneracionales; y las dinámicas temporales de los procesos biológicos en relación con la etapa del trastorno bajo investigación. Se espera que, en conjunto, estos artículos faciliten aún más el desarrollo de estrategias de intervención preventivas, tempranas y curativas más eficaces, así como una asignación mas eficaz, oportuna y personalizada a estas intervenciones.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Trauma-related disorders including posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) are associated with dysregulations in a wide range of biological processes. These processes include but are not confined to the central nervous system, autonomic nervous system; endocrine system; immune system and metabolic system. An extensive review of these systems and their associations with trauma-related is beyond the scope of this editorial, but interested readers are referred to the following recent overview paper (Shalev et al., 2024). Initial biological studies in our field mainly focused on the associations between biological measures and the presence or maintenance of trauma-related disorders. However, more recent studies provide accumulating evidence that biological dysregulations should not merely be considered as an acquired consequence of exposure to traumatic events or trauma-related disorders. In contrast, several biological processes seem to be associated with emotional and cognitive trauma processing and symptom onset, and are increasingly thought to contribute to individual differential susceptibility (i.e. risk or resilience) to the development of trauma-related disorders.

PTSD and other-trauma related disorders are highly prevalent and once their symptoms have established the odds for a chronic adverse course are considerable, even when evidence-based treatment is provided (Kessler et al., 2017; Semmlinger et al., 2024). Thus, further elucidation of the biological processes associated with the development of and susceptibility to trauma-related disorders is important to provide further avenues for much warranted preventive and early interventions to ameliorate long-term adverse mental health consequences of trauma. Therefore, this special issue focused on research aiming to advance our understanding of these biological processes. We specifically called for studies with adequate designs and setups to investigate biological processes in relation to relevant clinical, cognitive or behavioural aspects of trauma exposure and development of and susceptibility to trauma-related disorders, including prospective and longitudinal cohort studies, but also experimental, preclinical and computational studies. We specifically invited studies addressing: acute and long-term biological effects of traumatic stress; biological factors associated with risk and resilience to trauma-related disorders; biological processes of symptom onset and development after trauma; biological information to forecast mental health outcome after trauma; mediators and moderators of biological mechanisms of trauma-related disorders; intervention studies targeting or assessing biological processes associated with development of trauma-related disorders; impact of sex as a biological variable (SABV) on mental health outcome after trauma; other biological papers relevant to the field of psychotraumatology

sec.title: In this issue
sec.p: In this special issue we collected 51 papers accepted for publication in EJPT between 2021 and 2023.

The papers eventually selected for the special issue were either submitted specifically in response to the abovementioned call for papers until the end of 2022, or selected from articles accepted for publication in 2023 based on their clear biological focus. Forty-three of the included articles consisted of original research papers, with approximately 60% (n = 26) describing results of studies with cross-sectional study designs. The other original research papers presented results from studies with a prospective (n = 5); longitudinal (n = 4), experimental (i.e. analogue trauma) (n = 4) or clinical trial (n = 4) design. Within these original research articles, the overlarge majority (n = 32, 74.4%) focused on biological correlates of trauma-related psychiatric disorders or characteristic symptoms thereof, predominantly posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The remaining 11 original research papers concerned investigations of the associations between trauma exposure and biological processes, without considering its potential clinical consequences or in some instances excluding individuals with trauma-related disorders. Additionally, the special issue collection contains two narrative reviews, two systematic reviews with meta-analytic components, and four systematic reviews. Aligning with the trend observed in the original research papers, six of these focused specifically on PTSD or its symptoms, whilst the other two focused on the consequences of trauma exposure without a particular focus on its clinical consequences. All details of the papers are provided in the enclosed tables.

sec.title: Biological processes investigated
sec.p: The biological processes investigated within the articles included in this special issue can be broadly clustered as follows: brain/central nervous system; cardiovascular/autonomic nervous system; endocrinology; (epi)genetics; and a miscellaneous group including sleep, pain, metabolism and inflammation. Below the articles are clustered based on their primary biological focus, but please note that several articles focused on more than one of these processes.

sec.title: Brain / central nervous system
sec.p:
Brain and/or CNS-related research was the most prevalent primary focus of the articles accepted into the special issue, with 21 articles with this particular focus. Of these, 16 presented results from original research: One prospective study (Powers et al., 2022), one (Lan et al.) longitudinal study (Lan et al., 2023), and 14 studies with a cross-sectional design (Glazebrook et al., 2023; He et al., 2023; Hilberdink et al., 2021; Jin et al., 2023; Liddell et al., 2023; Rosada et al., 2021; Schellhaas et al., 2022; Sokołowski et al., 2022; Tamman et al., 2023; van Sleeuwen et al., 2023; Vicario et al., 2022; Wermuth et al., 2021; Xiao et al., 2023; Zhao et al., 2021) Of the remaining 5 articles not presenting original research, four consisted of systematic reviews (one including a meta-analytic investigation; (Askovic et al., 2023); purely systematic (Manthey et al., 2021; Nicholson et al., 2022; Susanty et al., 2022) and one consisted of a narrative review (Fine et al., 2023). The exact biological processes under investigation as well as the applied assessment methods for each of the 21 articles are depicted in Table 1. Table 1.

sec.title: Cardiovascular / autonomic nervous system
sec.p:
Ten of the articles within the special issue had a primary focus on cardiovascular and/or autonomic nervous system-related research. Of these, nine articles presented results from original research: 5 were cross-sectional studies (Bussone et al., 2023; Grasser et al., 2022; Krause-Utz et al., 2022; Noble et al., 2023; Schmitz et al., 2021), 2 were experimental studies (Beutler & Croy, 2023; Danböck et al., 2021) and 2 described results from clinical trials (Magnin et al., 2023; Roullet et al., 2022). The final article consisted of a systematic review (Beutler et al. 2022). The exact biological processes under investigation as well as the applied assessment methods for each of these 10 articles are depicted in Table 2. Table 2.

sec.title: Endocrinology
sec.p:
Eight of the articles within the special issue described original research results with a primary focus on endocrinology. These articles consisted of one prospective study (Yrondi et al., 2022), 3 cross-sectional studies (Krinke et al., 2022; Lee et al., 2022; Maslahati et al., 2023; Salvat-Pujol et al., 2021; Wadji et al., 2021), 2 experimental studies (Krinke et al., 2022; Maslahati et al., 2023), and 1 clinical trial (Engel et al., 2021). The final article consisted of a systematic review and meta-analysis (Engel et al., 2023). The exact biological processes under investigation as well as the applied assessment methods for each of these eight articles are depicted in Table 3. Table 3.

sec.title: (Epi)genetics
sec.p:
Six articles within the special issue primarily focused on epigenetic or genetic investigations. These studies all presented results from original research, with 2 articles described results from cross-sectional studies (Cusack et al., 2023; Mattonet et al., 2023); 2 articles describing results from longitudinal studies (dos Santos Oliveira et al., 2023; Elam et al., 2022) and 2 describing results from prospective studies (Gultig et al., 2023; Vuong et al., 2022). The exact biological processes under investigation as well as the applied assessment methods for each of these six articles are depicted in Table 4. Table 4.

sec.title: Miscellaneous
sec.p:
The remaining 6 articles contain a mixture of primary foci. Two original research articles focus on sleep, one with a cross-sectional (Ansbjerg et al., 2023) and one with a longitudinal design (Schenker et al., 2023). Three papers describe original research related to inflammatory and/or metabolic processes, including one cross-sectional study (Kurkinen et al., 2023), one prospective study (Baranyi et al., 2021) and one clinical trial (Maffioletti et al., 2021). The final article presents a narrative review encompassing a multitude of biological processes in relation to childhood trauma and physical pain (Campbell, 2022). The exact biological processes under investigation as well as the applied assessment methods for each of these six articles are depicted in Table 5. Table 5.

sec.title: Highlights and limitations
sec.p: Collectively, the included articles in our special issue investigated a wide range of biological processes in relation to trauma and trauma-related disorders, ranging from brain and central nervous system functioning; to cardiovascular and autonomic nervous system functioning; to endocrinology; (epi)genetics; metabolism; inflammation; sleep and pain. The most common research design of the included articles consisted of cross-sectional comparisons of biological measures between participants with or without trauma-related psychiatric disorders (mostly PTSD), or with or without previous trauma exposure. Many of these articles additionally incorporated other trauma-relevant psychological, cognitive and behavioural processes previously associated with mental health outcome following trauma, with the aim to shed light on potential mediators and moderators of the associations between the investigated biological processes and trauma exposure and its related disorders. Beyond the more traditional cross-sectional studies, we also included multiple articles with prospective, longitudinal, experimental designs as well as clinical treatment RCTs. These latter designs are better suited to investigate the temporal courses of the associations of the investigated biological processes with trauma exposure, and with the development, maintenance as well as the recovery of trauma-related disorders. Therefore, we recommend future studies aiming to obtain more mechanistic insights to prioritise such designs over cross-sectional designs.

We were happy to see that the participant samples investigated in the included articles were quite diverse in terms of demographic and exposure characteristics. In terms of recruitment location, many of the investigated samples extended well beyond the so called WEIRD (Western, Educated, Industrial, Rich, and Democratic) populations, facilitating generalizability of findings to the global population. Furthermore, whilst most investigated samples in this issue consisted of adults, several studies focused specifically on childhood, adolescence or young or late adulthood (for a systematic review on biopsychosocial factors that may influence the onset and persistence of PTSD in children and adolescence also see (Williams et al., 2024). Furthermore, 3 studies assessed child-adult family dyads and even triads (Elam et al., 2022; Mattonet et al., 2023; Wadji et al., 2021). As such, these studies will contribute to elucidating the developmental and even transgenerational aspects of trauma and how these may impact potential adverse mental health outcomes. Future studies would ideally include even more varied and understudied populations in terms of location as well as developmental and aging perspectives.

Participants across articles had been exposed to a wide variety of (potential) traumatic events. This is relevant as trauma characteristics, including the type of trauma exposure, are known to impact the risk for subsequent development of trauma-related disorders including PTSD, as well as their course and phenotypical symptom expression (Brewin et al., 2025). However, in particular for the cross-sectional and clinical intervention studies, trauma type and the broader trauma history were often not specified or taken into account otherwise. Not all included articles in this special issue strictly specified trauma according to the DSM-5 definition, instead investigating populations with more chronic and perhaps more insidious stress exposure (e.g. Elam et al., 2022; Gultig et al., 2023). As there is ongoing debate about the optimal conceptualisation and demarcation of what experiences should be considered traumatic (Marx et al., 2024), such studies will contribute to explorations of potential similarities and differences in the biological correlates between these types of exposures. Therefore, to advance our understanding of if and how these characteristics interact with the biological processes associated with trauma exposure trauma-related adverse biological outcomes, it is recommended that future biological studies incorporate trauma exposure characteristics into their descriptive and analytic approach.

Accumulating findings support that many of biological processes investigated in the included articles are temporally dynamic: their functioning as well as their associations with trauma-related disorders depend on the time since trauma exposure onset and exact stage of the disorder at the time of assessment. These observations fit with the more recent perspective that psychiatric disorders including PTSD and other-trauma related disorders should be approached from a staging perspective, if we are to better understand their etiology and prognosis and improve treatment outcomes (Burback et al., 2024). The timing of assessments relative to exposure and symptom onset is commonly well reported for prospective studies, including those within the special issue. Additionally, the included experimental studies inducing so-called analogue traumatic stress had detailed reporting on the exact timing of their peri- and acute post-‘traumatic’ assessments (Beutler & Croy, 2023; Danböck et al., 2021; Krinke et al., 2022; Maslahati et al., 2023). However, most of the included cross-sectional, longitudinal and clinical intervention studies did either not provide this information, or merely stated or implied a ‘long’ duration since trauma or disorder onset without any further specification (e.g. in the case of childhood trauma investigations in adults). Thus, for any biological measure, it is recommended to specify when it was measured in relation to the trauma exposure and the stage of the disorder of interest.

Over the past decade it has become increasingly clear that the biological mechanisms underlying trauma-related disorders are influenced by sex and sex-related factors, as well as gender (minority)-related factors (Langeland & Olff, 2024). Although the EJPT was the first journal to adopt a gender policy (Olff, 2016) most of the included articles did not explicitly address the potential impact of these factors in their analytic approach. Most articles combined women and men into one sample without investigating potentially differential biological effects of sex and/or gender. Others investigated only women or men but did not take sex and/or gender (minority)-related factors into account. Less than a handful of papers in this special issue purposefully investigated sex and gender-differential effects (Gultig et al., 2023; Schenker et al., 2023) or the impact of sex hormone-related factors (Krinke et al., 2022; Maslahati et al., 2023), although many of the included articles noted this as a relevant limitation in their discussion. Hence, it is recommended that future biological trauma studies further investigate sex and/or gender effects.

sec.title: Conclusions and future research
sec.p:
The large number of articles included in this special issue shows biological research into trauma and trauma-related disorders is thriving. Collectively, the included articles showcase that significant steps are taken to advance our understanding of the biological mechanisms underlying the development of and susceptibility to trauma-related disorders, as well the recovery from these disorders. Our hope is that this increasing knowledge base will eventually facilitate the development of more effective preventive, early and curative intervention strategies, as well as more effective personalised interventions and timely allocation towards these interventions. This is highly pertinent, as trauma-related disorders remain a significant public health problem given the ongoing high lifetime prevalence of these disorders (Kessler et al., 2017), and the fact that evidence-based treatments are not sufficiently effective for a considerable part of treatment-receiving patients (Semmlinger et al., 2024). In the preceding section we outlined several important recommendations should be taken into account in future biological research into trauma and trauma-related disorders: trauma exposure characteristics; sex and/or gender (minority)-related factors; developmental/lifespan and transgenerational aspects; and the temporal dynamics of biological processes in relation to the stage of the disorder under investigation. We therefore recommend that future biological studies into trauma-related disorders carefully consider which study designs and statistical and computational methodological approaches are appropriate to truly disentangle the effects of these factors on the biological mechanisms behind adverse mental health outcomes of trauma (see Box 1). Box 1.Recommendations for future biological research on trauma-related disorders
Study design
Prioritise prospective, longitudinal, experimental, and clinical RCT designs to better capture temporal dynamics and causal mechanisms.
Carefully select appropriate statistical and computational methods to disentangle complex interactions between biological, psychological, and contextual factors.
Sample diversity
Include more diverse and underrepresented populations across:
- Geographic regions
- Developmental stages/lifespan
- Transgenerational effects
Trauma exposure characteristics
Clearly specify and incorporate:
- Type of trauma
- Trauma history
- Developmental timing of trauma exposure
Consider broader definitions of trauma, including chronic and insidious stressors.
Temporal dynamics
Report when biological measures were taken relative to:
- Trauma exposure
- Stage of disorder (onset, maintenance, recovery)
Sex and gender Considerations
Explicitly analyse sex- and gender-related factors
Avoid aggregating sexes/genders without testing for differential effects.

sec.title: Disclosure statement
sec.p: No potential conflict of interest was reported by the authors.
